channel.title: International: Top News And Analysis
channel.description: CNBC International is the world leader for news on business, technology, China, trade, oil prices, the Middle East and markets.

item.title: The Fed is expected to raise rates by a half point. Investors wonder if it will get more aggressive
item.description: Investors are focused on whether the Federal Reserve will signal an even more aggressive rate-hiking path going forward.

item.title: AMD sales jump 71%, shrugging off concerns about PC slowdown
item.description: AMD reported first-quarter earnings after the bell on Tuesday, beating analyst estimates for earnings and revenue.

item.title: Starbucks suspends its outlook as Covid lockdowns hammer sales in China
item.description: It's Howard Schultz's first earnings report since taking back the top job at Starbucks in early April.

item.title: Australia stocks set for higher start as investors look ahead to Fed rate decision
item.description: The U.S. Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates on Wednesday for the second time since 2018.

item.title: What's the best hotel for business travel? Take CNBC's survey and tell us your favorite
item.description: If you feel strongly about what makes a hotel great for business trips — and we're betting you do — then now's the time to weigh in.

item.title: Beijing city closes gyms and bans dining in as Covid controls tighten
item.description: Over the weekend, the capital city of Beijing closed theme parks and banned dining in restaurants to control Covid — just as a five-day holiday got underway.

item.title: Paul Tudor Jones says he can't think of a worse financial environment for stocks or bonds right now
item.description: Paul Tudor Jones said the environment for investors is worse than ever as the Fed is raising rates when financial conditions have become increasingly tight.

item.title: Citi says a trader error caused Europe’s ‘flash crash.’ Here's how it unfolded
item.description: U.S. banking giant Citigroup has taken responsibility for the flash crash which saw some European stocks turn sharply lower.

item.title: Why solo female travelers are joining group tours
item.description: Solo travel is typically associated with flexibility, and group tours are seen as rigid. So why are female solo travelers signing up for this style of travel?

item.title: Peter Thiel's luxury New Zealand lodge should be rejected, council planner says
item.description: Peter Thiel's proposed lodge in New Zealand hangs in the balance after a senior planner for the local council said the development should be rejected.

item.title: Airbnb beats estimates with 70% revenue growth as travel rebounds
item.description: Airbnb said it's seen substantial growth in bookings despite pandemic concerns, "macroeconomic headwinds" and the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Portraits of war: See how the attack on Ukraine has affected its people
item.description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine in late February, more than 3,100 people have died.

item.title: Natural gas surges as much as 9% to highest level since 2008 as Russia's war roils energy markets
item.description: U.S. natural gas prices have more than doubled this year as Russia's war in Ukraine wreaks havoc on global energy markets.

item.title: Russia races to avert historic default as bondholders wait for dollar payments
item.description: Russia looks set to meet another deadline for debt payments on Wednesday after tapping its domestic foreign currency reserves to avert a historic sovereign default.

item.title: Supreme Court says leaked abortion draft is authentic; Roberts orders investigation into leak
item.description: Roberts noted that the Supreme Court draft ruling, which would overturn decades-old abortion protections, does not represent the court's final decision.

item.title: EU considers exemptions to push through Russian oil embargo
item.description: Russia's unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, and evidence of war crimes, has pushed the EU to take bolder steps on energy sanctions.

item.title: Stocks rise for second straight day ahead of expected Fed hike
item.description: U.S. equities built on their gains after a late rally on Monday.

item.title: Russia's Nazi claims provoke outrage in Israel: Here's what you need to know
item.description: A rift between Russia and Israel that emerged at the weekend has deepened further.

item.title: Can crypto go green? Major companies are trying — but it's easier said than done
item.description: The whole process behind cryptocurrency mining is underpinned by something known as "proof of work." And it uses up an incredibly large amount of energy.

item.title: The Great Resignation is still red hot — but may not last
item.description: The "Great Resignation" is still red-hot but economic headwinds mean those benefits may not last much longer for workers looking to switch jobs.

item.title: Office demand comes roaring back as stocks in the space play catch-up
item.description: After a five-month lull due to the omicron variant, office demand is surging back again, albeit slowly for the office stocks.

item.title: Leaked draft Supreme Court decision would overturn Roe v. Wade abortion rights ruling, Politico report says
item.description: For nearly 50 years the constitutional right to abortion has been protected by the Supreme Court decision in the Roe v. Wade case. An imminent ruling could upend that.

item.title: BP reports bumper first-quarter net profit, but posts massive loss on hit from Russia exit
item.description: BP announced a further $2.5 billion in share buybacks as it reported its highest first-quarter profit in more than a decade.

item.title: Tomb Raider publisher sells iconic video game franchise to invest in blockchain
item.description: Japan's Square Enix is selling the Tomb Raider franchise to Sweden's Embracer Group in a $300 million deal.

item.title: 10-year Treasury yield dips below 3%; benchmark German bund yield hits 1%
item.description: The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield traded below the 3% mark on Tuesday, while the 10-year German Bund hit 1% for the first time since 2015.

item.title: Fears of a Fed mistake grow as this week's anticipated interest rate hike looms
item.description: The Federal Reserve is tasked with slowing the U.S. economy enough to control inflation but not so much that it tips into recession.

item.title: Australia hikes its interest rate for the first time in more than a decade
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia said the cash rate will be increased by 25 basis points to 0.35% — the first rate hike since November 2010.

item.title: Chip supply issues are still giving some of world's biggest companies a major headache
item.description: An ongoing shortage of chips and other basic materials is forcing tech and automotive giants to scale back their targets.

item.title: Finland has walked a political tightrope between Moscow and the West for decades. But that could be about to end
item.description: Finland could be about to announce that it's joining the military alliance NATO — in what would mark a dramatic U-turn for its foreign policy.

item.title: Alibaba's shares fall in Hong Kong following unconfirmed rumors linking Jack Ma to probe
item.description: Alibaba's Hong Kong-listed shares fell Tuesday after unconfirmed rumors linked the internet tech giant's founder Jack Ma to a national security investigation.
